comments.raw_text:
sure. fx8.png is firefox 8, moz2.png is seamonkey 2

The problem appears towards the second half of the page, the beginning of the page looks fine.

Now that you say it works okay with you, i tried mozilla, chrome, and safari
Moz and Fx both indicate that there's a problem, but the problem manifests itself differently (but in the same area of the page, give or take) as you can see in the attached screenshots

in webkit (chrome and safari) everything is okay

In Fx8 i have a bunch of addons installed as you can see in Fx8-addons.png, but in seamonkey there are no addons installed. Also, i tried to disable all addons in Fx (just *disabled*, not uninstalled), and the problem persists.

Maybe it's just a video card issue with my system (i have Radeon Xpress 1150), or maybe it has to do with the installed addons? anywayz, if more people say the page looks okay on their system it's prolly something wrong with mine.

gyll@iname.com
comments.creator: gyll@iname.com
comments.text:
1) my drivers are up to date (at least that's what windowsupdate says)
2) forgot to mention that in opera everything is fine too
3) some more info, maybe it helps:
if:
a) i first scroll to the bottom of the page (such that the layout get scrambled) and then incrementally scroll upwards till the point where the "break" appears, then
b) i minimize the window (i.e. it is removed from the desktop), and finally
c) i restore the fx window (i.e. the window is redisplayed on the desktop)
then, *at the point where the layout breaks* in the document the text looks okay (i.e. simply repainting the window paints it correctly) - this is shown in fx8-break-point-before-repaint.png and fx8-break-point-after-repaint.png

However, if i do the same sequence lower down the document (i.e. where the layout is corrupted), then the window repainting does not fix the rendering problem (i'm not uploading files for this scenario cause there's nothing to see: before and after look the same if the document area that is being displayed is *below* the breaking point)
comments.raw_text:
1) my drivers are up to date (at least that's what windowsupdate says)
2) forgot to mention that in opera everything is fine too
3) some more info, maybe it helps:
if:
a) i first scroll to the bottom of the page (such that the layout get scrambled) and then incrementally scroll upwards till the point where the "break" appears, then
b) i minimize the window (i.e. it is removed from the desktop), and finally
c) i restore the fx window (i.e. the window is redisplayed on the desktop)
then, *at the point where the layout breaks* in the document the text looks okay (i.e. simply repainting the window paints it correctly) - this is shown in fx8-break-point-before-repaint.png and fx8-break-point-after-repaint.png

However, if i do the same sequence lower down the document (i.e. where the layout is corrupted), then the window repainting does not fix the rendering problem (i'm not uploading files for this scenario cause there's nothing to see: before and after look the same if the document area that is being displayed is *below* the breaking point)

comments.text:
one more thing: on my ATI driver settings i can disable "write combining", but setting the acceleration to "none" doesn't do anything (there's no visible effect, and it automatically gets reset to "full" when windows restarts).

So i disabled "write combining" in the video driver (i.e. the best i could do to disable accels), and i also disabled "use h/w accel  when available" in firefox, but the behavior remains the same (i.e. the rendering problem persists).
comments.raw_text:
one more thing: on my ATI driver settings i can disable "write combining", but setting the acceleration to "none" doesn't do anything (there's no visible effect, and it automatically gets reset to "full" when windows restarts).

So i disabled "write combining" in the video driver (i.e. the best i could do to disable accels), and i also disabled "use h/w accel  when available" in firefox, but the behavior remains the same (i.e. the rendering problem persists).
comments.creator: gyll@iname.com
comments.author: gyll@iname.com

comments.creator: gyll@iname.com
comments.author: gyll@iname.com
comments.text: and yet one more thing: i said in comment #9 that i'm minimizing and then restoring the firefox window with the document area that is displayed inside the window being "at the breaking point"; this is not actually accurate: the breaking point is actually RIGHT BELOW the area of the document that is being displayed: the display is shown scrambled at that document position *only because i scrolled from the bottom of the document upwards* (i.e. from the bottom area of the document where the display is scrambled towards the upper area where the document is displayed correctly); if i go to the very same point that is shown in fx8-break-point-before-repaint.png FROM THE TOP OF THE DOCUMENT DOWNWARDS, then the display AT THAT POINT is correct.
comments.raw_text: and yet one more thing: i said in comment #9 that i'm minimizing and then restoring the firefox window with the document area that is displayed inside the window being "at the breaking point"; this is not actually accurate: the breaking point is actually RIGHT BELOW the area of the document that is being displayed: the display is shown scrambled at that document position *only because i scrolled from the bottom of the document upwards* (i.e. from the bottom area of the document where the display is scrambled towards the upper area where the document is displayed correctly); if i go to the very same point that is shown in fx8-break-point-before-repaint.png FROM THE TOP OF THE DOCUMENT DOWNWARDS, then the display AT THAT POINT is correct.
